title: I don't like that Warmog's has CDR now and here's why
body:
I'd rather have the HP and more build flexibility. I want Warmogs when I'm either going to play very aggro and then back off or I'm taking a lot of poke. I shouldn't have to worry about whether it'll take me over the cap or not. I'd rather that power was channeled into some other aspect. Right now, there are almost too many CDR items and it's making it harder to pick them for the niche I want because of wasting CDR.

btw: thoughts on Frozen Heart?

replies.body: You don't get penalized for building more than 40% CDR. You know that right? Who cares if building Warmogs will put you over 40% sometimes; you either want Warmogs or you don't and the 10% CDR it now has shouldn't affect your decision on whether or not to get it.
The gold you spend for the unused CDR is wasted, in a way, perhaps. The "penalty" for going over the cap is the gold that could have gone towards another item is going towards unused stats.

Is Warmogs still better than the alternative without considering the CDR? Yes? Then you still get it. It's really that simple.

And realistically, how are you going to go over 40% CDR on a tank anyway? {{item:3110}} {{item:3065}} {{item:3083}} is a clean 40%, I don't know what other CDR you would even want to build.

Those 3 plus banner of command and a lot of hp make split pushing easy. Plus they're pretty cheap. I built zzrot on morgana after losing two turrets and held the 3rd one for a LONG time. Made 2k gold on it and 2k gold on frost fang by timing my w around when my passive was active. Banner of command was easily dispatched because it was easier to notice than those purple voidlings. These I keep seperate because they are primarily played in support.  Other tanks have been played in support, but for the purpose of this discussion we'll use their intended roles of Top, mid, and jungle (Blitzcrank is an interesting case because he was actually originally built for top, but multiple seasons of supporting have thrust him into the support lane for what his kit offers). 


{{champion:12}} {{champion:32}} {{champion:31}} {{champion:3}} {{champion:54}} {{champion:57}} {{champion:111}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:33}} {{champion:113}} {{champion:98}} {{champion:14}} {{champion:154}} 

Now one thing you should notice about all of these champions is that tank is their **primary** role.  Their **secondary** role doesn't really matter much at all in classification (there are exceptions of course.  But exceptions are not the rule.  If that were the case, {{champion:101}} would be considered an assassin).  

But there is more to it than just that.  Each of these champions has some form of CC or built in peel mechanism.  {{champion:12}} has his headbutt and knock up.  {{champion:201}} has his slow, stun passive, and knock up ult.  {{champion:32}} has two stuns.  {{champion:57}} root and knock up.  {{champion:98}} and {{champion:3}} have taunts on top of effects that benefit allies defensively.  {{champion:78}} has a wall stun, an anti dash field, and a disengage ult that can be used offensively.

I'm not going to describe every champions ability, that will make this more of a text wall.  

No I'll show you what shows up when you choose tanks in the shop rather than look at their primary search in the champions filter on your profile in the client (because the client still has some old functions and (as you pointed out) Riot has not actually input the new classes and subclasses into the client.  **This does not mean that they are not to be used.**).

{{champion:266}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:120}} {{champion:106}} {{champion:102}} {{champion:62}} {{champion:58}} {{champion:48}} {{champion:36}} {{champion:86}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:2}} {{champion:77}} {{champion:19}} {{champion:8}} {{champion:420}} {{champion:83}} 

Now these champions have tank as their **secondary**.  Meaning they have some aspects of a tank, but not enough to actually allow them to be a proper tank for a team.  Their are at best, meatshields that provide huge damage.  Because that is what their kits are built for, dealing damage and surviving fights. 

Tank kits are not designed to deal fighter (which is what those champions primarily are) level damage.  Tanks can do damage, but only enough to make glass cannons afraid of them.  These fighters do not have the same level of utility as actual tanks.  Mundo just has a slow.  Darius has a hook with a short range.  Nasus has a slow, and it's a damn powerful one, but he can only hit one target, which is mainly so that when he's at a massive number of stacks, he can kill that target by preventing them to run away.  

There are obvious outliers, as Riot pointed out there would be in the subclasses.  {{champion:72}} for example was originally a juggernaut, but Riot plans on switching him to the vanguard class due to how his kit actually works.  

{{champion:27}} is primarily a tank, but has such a weird kit that I can't imagine him really fitting into the role.  Especially how he's a primarily split push champion and tanks are more teamfight focused.  I guess you could call him a split push juggernaut.  

{{champion:59}} is primarily a tank, but his numbers have been changed so much that he's either played as a full AD assassin or a form of bruiser.  So I'm not sure I can consider him to be one.  I'll be fine if I am wrong though.

Interesting tidbit: Tanks can build like fighters and fighters can build like tanks.  They use very similar items (mainly the health part).  It's just that many tanks do not actually function as well as fighters when building like a fighter, and vice versa (though of course people will still call tanks broken if {{champion:86}} has no AD items yet one hit kills the villain with his ult while the villain is low).

{{champion:79}} was an AP bruiser, but his utility has made him into more of a tank in the recent years and will probably be labeled as such.

{{champion:421}} has become a knock up bot.  I don't know what Riot plans for her.

{{champion:150}}: I personally don't think he's in his mega form enough to count as a tank, but that's what Riot calls him.

Though if you didn't want to read all of this or still have doubts as to what Riot considers a tank.  Please read the following link.

You do indirectly because you're not using an item to its maximal efficiency. It matters a lot because your build relative to opponents will be less effective and you're not spiking as hard from it. It's like playing Mundo and buying no HP items. You're not penalized but he was balanced around the idea that you'd take advantage of his HP scalings and when you don't build that way, he becomes much weaker. Items were also designed with balance around the idea that a champion can use all its stats so if you go over the cap for CDR, it always means there's a problem with your build and you aren't doing something right.
Efficiency doesn't occur in a vacuum m8. Stats are only worth as much as they do for you.
